title: When Should My Child See an Orthodontist? A Parent's Complete Guide
excerpt: Learn the optimal timing for your child's first orthodontic consultation and what signs to watch for that indicate your child may need braces or other orthodontic treatment.
author: Dr. Joshua Kohan

content.text: The Importance of Early Orthodontic Evaluation

As a parent in Chino, CA, you might wonder when the right time is to take your child to see an orthodontist. The American Association of Orthodontists recommends that children have their first orthodontic evaluation by age 7. This might seem early, but there are important reasons for this timing.
Why Age 7 is the Magic Number

By age 7, most children have a mix of baby teeth and permanent teeth. This allows our pediatric orthodontist in Chino to evaluate how the teeth and jaws are developing and identify potential issues early. Early detection doesn't always mean immediate treatment, but it allows us to monitor your child's development and plan the best timing for treatment if needed.
Signs Your Child May Need Orthodontic Treatment

items: Early or late loss of baby teeth
Jaws that shift or make sounds
Teeth that don't come together properly

content.text: Benefits of Early Orthodontic Treatment
When orthodontic issues are caught early, treatment can often be simpler and more effective. Early intervention can:

items: Regulate the width of the upper and lower dental arches
Avoid the need for tooth removal later

content.text: What Happens During an Orthodontic Consultation in Chino?

During your child's first visit to our Chino orthodontic office, Dr. Kohan will conduct a thorough examination, which may include X-rays and photographs. We'll discuss any concerns you have and explain our findings in terms that are easy to understand. If treatment is recommended, we'll create a customized plan that works for your family's schedule and budget.

Remember, every child is unique, and the timing for orthodontic treatment varies. Some children benefit from early treatment (Phase 1), while others are better served by waiting until most permanent teeth have erupted. Trust the expertise of your pediatric orthodontist in Chino to guide you through this important decision.

title: How to Make Your Child Comfortable at the Pediatric Dentist
excerpt: Discover proven strategies to help reduce your child's dental anxiety and create positive experiences at our Chino pediatric dental office.
author: Dr. Joshua Kohan

content.text: Creating Positive Dental Experiences for Children

Visiting the dentist can be intimidating for children, but with the right approach, dental appointments can become positive experiences that set the foundation for a lifetime of good oral health. At Say Cheese Kids Dental in Chino, we've helped thousands of children overcome dental anxiety.
Before the Appointment: Preparation is Key
Start preparing your child for their dental visit a few days in advance, but not too early to avoid building up anxiety. Here are some effective strategies:
Use Positive Language

Instead of saying "The dentist won't hurt you," try "The dentist will help keep your teeth healthy and strong." Focus on the positive aspects of dental care rather than introducing the concept of pain or discomfort.
Read Books About Dental Visits
There are many children's books about visiting the dentist that can help familiarize your child with what to expect. These stories often feature characters who have positive dental experiences.
Role Play at Home
Let your child play "dentist" with their toys or stuffed animals. This helps them feel more in control and familiar with the concept of dental examinations.
During the Visit: What to Expect at Our Chino Office
Our pediatric dental office in Chino is specifically designed with children in mind. We create a welcoming, fun environment that helps children feel at ease from the moment they walk in.
Child-Friendly Environment
Our office features bright colors, fun decorations, and entertainment options that keep children engaged and distracted from any potential anxiety.
Gentle Communication
Dr. Kohan and our team use child-friendly language to explain procedures. We might call the dental drill a "tooth tickler" or the suction device a "vacuum cleaner for teeth."
Show-Tell-Do Approach
We show children the instruments we'll use, explain what they do, and then demonstrate on a model before using them in their mouth. This helps reduce fear of the unknown.
Managing Dental Anxiety in Children
If your child experiences significant dental anxiety, we offer several approaches to help them feel more comfortable:

items: Nitrous Oxide (Laughing Gas): A safe, mild sedation that helps children relax
Oral Sedation: For children with severe anxiety, we may recommend mild oral sedation
Distraction Techniques: Music, videos, or games during treatment
Frequent Breaks: We allow children to take breaks during longer procedures

content.text: After the Visit: Reinforcing Positive Experiences
Celebrate your child's successful dental visit! Praise their bravery and cooperation. Consider a small reward or special activity (that's not sugary!) to mark the occasion.
Building Long-Term Dental Health Habits

Regular dental visits from an early age help children develop comfort with dental care and establish healthy oral hygiene habits. At our Chino pediatric dental practice, we're committed to making every visit positive and educational.

Remember, your attitude as a parent greatly influences your child's feelings about dental care. Stay positive, trust our experienced team, and don't hesitate to communicate any concerns you have about your child's comfort during their visit.

title: Top 5 Tips for Children's Oral Health: A Chino Pediatric Dentist's Guide
excerpt: Essential oral hygiene tips from our experienced pediatric dentist to keep your child's teeth healthy and prevent cavities.
author: Dr. Joshua Kohan

content.text: Building Strong Oral Health Habits in Children

As a pediatric dentist in Chino, CA, I see firsthand how proper oral care from an early age can set children up for a lifetime of healthy smiles. Here are my top 5 tips for maintaining excellent oral health in children.
1. Start Early with Proper Brushing Technique

Good oral hygiene should begin even before your child's first tooth appears. Wipe your baby's gums with a clean, damp cloth after feeding. Once teeth emerge, use a soft-bristled toothbrush designed for infants.
Age-Appropriate Brushing Guidelines

items: Ages 0-2: Use a rice-grain sized amount of fluoride toothpaste
Ages 3-6: Use a pea-sized amount of fluoride toothpaste
Ages 6+: Children can begin brushing independently with supervision

content.text: Teach your child to brush for two minutes, twice daily. Make it fun with songs, timers, or electric toothbrushes with built-in timers.
2. Don't Forget About Flossing
Once your child has two teeth that touch, it's time to start flossing. Many parents in Chino ask me when to begin flossing, and the answer is earlier than most people think!
For young children, use floss picks or water flossers to make the process easier. As they get older, teach them proper flossing technique using traditional dental floss.
3. Maintain a Tooth-Friendly Diet
What your child eats and drinks has a major impact on their oral health. Here's what I recommend to families in our Chino pediatric dental practice:
Foods to Include

items: Dairy products (milk, cheese, yogurt) for calcium and phosphorus
Leafy greens and vegetables for vitamins and minerals

content.text: Foods to Limit

items: Sticky foods that cling to teeth

content.text: 4. Schedule Regular Dental Checkups

The American Academy of Pediatric Dentistry recommends that children visit the dentist by their first birthday or within six months of their first tooth appearing. After that, regular checkups every six months help prevent problems and catch issues early.
During these visits at our Chino office, we:

items: Apply fluoride treatments to strengthen teeth
Check for cavities and other issues
Provide education on proper oral care

content.text: 5. Protect Teeth During Sports and Activities

If your child participates in contact sports or activities with a risk of mouth injury, a custom mouthguard is essential. At our Chino dental office, we can create a perfectly fitted mouthguard that provides superior protection compared to over-the-counter options.
Additional Protection Tips

items: Avoid using teeth as tools (opening packages, etc.)
Break habits like thumb sucking or nail biting
Encourage helmet use during biking and skating

content.text: Creating Positive Oral Health Habits

The key to successful pediatric oral care is making it routine and enjoyable. Create a fun bedtime routine that includes brushing and flossing. Consider reward charts for younger children who consistently follow their oral care routine.
When to Call Your Chino Pediatric Dentist
Contact our office immediately if your child experiences:

items: Swelling in the face or mouth
White spots on teeth (early signs of decay)

content.text: Remember, establishing good oral health habits early sets the foundation for a lifetime of healthy smiles. If you have questions about your child's oral health or would like to schedule a consultation, don't hesitate to contact our Chino pediatric dental office.

title: Understanding Pediatric Dental Emergencies: What Chino Parents Need to Know
excerpt: Learn how to handle common dental emergencies in children and when to seek immediate care from your pediatric dentist in Chino, CA.
author: Dr. Joshua Kohan

content.text: Handling Pediatric Dental Emergencies with Confidence

Dental emergencies in children can be frightening for both kids and parents. As a pediatric dentist serving Chino and surrounding areas, I want to help parents understand how to handle common dental emergencies and when to seek immediate professional care.
Common Pediatric Dental Emergencies
1. Knocked-Out Tooth (Avulsed Tooth)
For Permanent Teeth:

items: Find the tooth and pick it up by the crown (not the root)
Rinse gently with water if dirty, but don't scrub
Try to reinsert the tooth into the socket if possible
If reinsertion isn't possible, store in milk or saliva

content.text: For Baby Teeth:

items: Do NOT try to reinsert a knocked-out baby tooth
Contact our Chino office for guidance

content.text: 2. Cracked or Broken Teeth

Rinse the mouth with warm water and apply a cold compress to reduce swelling. Save any tooth fragments if possible. Contact our emergency line for immediate advice on whether immediate care is needed.
3. Severe Toothache

Clean around the affected tooth gently with warm water. Check for trapped food particles and remove with dental floss if present. Never put aspirin or other medications directly on the gums. Call our Chino office for pain management advice and scheduling.
4. Objects Stuck Between Teeth
Try to remove the object with dental floss. Never use sharp instruments that could damage the gums or push the object further. If unsuccessful, contact our pediatric dental office in Chino.
When to Seek Immediate Emergency Care
Contact our emergency line immediately if your child experiences:

items: Swelling of the face, gums, or mouth
Signs of infection (fever, pus, bad taste)
Trauma to the face or mouth
A permanent tooth that's been knocked out

content.text: Preventing Dental Emergencies
While accidents happen, many dental emergencies can be prevented:
Sports Safety
Home Safety

items: Childproof your home to prevent falls
Avoid hard foods that can crack teeth
Don't let children chew on ice, pens, or hard objects
Regular dental checkups to catch problems early

What to Expect During Emergency Visits
When you bring your child to our Chino emergency dental clinic, we:

items: Assess the situation quickly and thoroughly
Use gentle techniques appropriate for children

content.text: Follow-Up Care

After emergency treatment, follow-up care is crucial for proper healing. We'll provide detailed instructions for home care and schedule necessary follow-up appointments to monitor your child's recovery.

Remember, staying calm during a dental emergency helps your child stay calm too. Our experienced team in Chino is here to provide compassionate, expert care when your child needs it most. Don't hesitate to call our emergency line - we're always here to help.

content.text: Your Complete Guide to Kids Braces and Orthodontic Treatment

Choosing orthodontic treatment for your child is an important decision that can significantly impact their oral health and confidence. As a pediatric orthodontist in Chino, CA, I want to provide parents with comprehensive information about kids braces and what to expect during treatment.
Types of Braces for Children and Teens
Traditional Metal Braces
Metal braces remain the most common and effective option for kids. Modern metal braces are smaller and more comfortable than ever before.
Advantages:

items: Suitable for all types of orthodontic issues

content.text: Best for: Children with complex orthodontic issues, active kids who play sports, and families looking for the most economical option.
Clear Ceramic Braces
Ceramic braces work the same way as metal braces but use tooth-colored or clear brackets that blend with natural teeth.
Advantages:

items: Good option for teens concerned about appearance

content.text: Considerations:

items: Slightly more expensive than metal braces
Brackets can stain if not properly cared for

content.text: Invisalign Teen
Clear aligners that are removable and nearly invisible, designed specifically for teenagers.
Advantages:
Requirements:

items: Must be worn 20-22 hours per day
Not suitable for all orthodontic issues
Typically recommended for teens 13 and older

content.text: Orthodontic Treatment Timeline
Phase 1 Treatment (Early Intervention)
Age: 7-10 years old
Duration: 12-18 months
Purpose: Guide jaw growth, create space for permanent teeth, and address harmful oral habits.
Phase 2 Treatment (Comprehensive Treatment)
Age: 11-14 years old (when most permanent teeth have erupted)
Duration: 18-30 months average
Purpose: Align all permanent teeth and perfect the bite.
